text: CONSEQUENCES OF ILLICIT DRUG USE IN AMERICA
label: HH1

text: Drug Deaths
label: BODY

text: 38,371 people died of drug-induced causes in 2007, the latest year for which data are available.  The number of
label: BODY

text: drug-induced deaths has grown from 19,128 in 1999, or from 6.8 deaths per 100,000 population to 12.6 in 2007.1
label: BODY

text: (These include causes directly involving drugs, such as accidental poisoning or overdoses, but do not include
label: BODY

text: accidents, homicides, AIDS, and other causes indirectly related to drugs.)
label: BODY

text: There is a drug-induced death in the U.S. every 15 minutes.2
label: BODY

text: Compared to other causes of preventable deaths, drug-induced causes exceeded the 31,224 deaths from injuries
label: BODY

text: due to firearms and the 23,199 alcohol-induced deaths recorded in 2007.  In the same year, 34,598 deaths were
label: BODY

text: classified as suicides and 18,361 deaths as homicides.3
label: BODY

text: Drugged Driving
label: BODY

text: From a national roadside survey in 2007, one in eight (12.4%) of weekend nighttime drivers tested positive for at
label: BODY

text: least one illicit drug.4
label: BODY

text: Based on a self-report survey in 2009, approximately 10.5 million Americans reported driving under the influence
label: BODY

text: of an illicit drug during the past year.5
label: BODY

text: In 2009, one in three drivers killed in motor vehicle crashes who were tested for drugs and the results known,
label: BODY

text: tested positive for at least one medication or illicit drug.6
label: BODY

text: Among high school seniors in 2008, one in 10 (10.4%) reported that in the two weeks prior to their interview,
label: BODY

text: they had driven a vehicle after smoking marijuana.7
label: BODY

text: Children
label: BODY

text: Annual averages for 2002 to 2007 indicate that over 8.3 million youth under 18 years of age, or almost one in
label: BODY

text: eight youth (11.9%), lived with at least one parent who was dependent on alcohol or an illicit drug in the past
label: BODY

text: year.8  Of these, About 2.1 million youth lived with a parent who was dependent on or abused illicit drugs, and
label: BODY

text: almost 7.3 million lived with a parent who was dependent on or abused alcohol.9
label: BODY

text: School Performance
label: BODY

text: Significantly fewer youth in school who are current marijuana users report an average grade of “A” (12.5%)
label: BODY

text: compared to those who are not current marijuana users (30.5% report an average grade of “A”).10
label: BODY

text: College students who use prescription stimulant medications nonmedically typically have lower grade point
label: BODY

text: averages, are more likely to be heavy drinkers and users of other illicit drugs, and are more likely to meet
label: BODY

text: diagnostic criteria for dependence on alcohol and marijuana, skip class more frequently, and spend less time
label: BODY

text: studying. 11
label: BODY

text: Economic Costs
label: BODY

text: The economic cost of drug abuse in the US was estimated at $180.9 billion in 2002, the last available estimate.
label: BODY

text: This value represents both the use of resources to address health and crime consequences as well as the loss of
label: BODY

text: potential productivity from disability, premature death, and withdrawal from the legitimate workforce.12
label: BODY

text: ONDCP seeks to foster healthy individuals and safe communities by effectively
label: BODY

text: leading the Nation’s effort to reduce drug use and its consequences.
label: BODY

text: December 2010
label: BODY

text: Addiction and Treatment Need
label: BODY

text: In 2009, 23.5 million persons aged 12 or older needed treatment for an illicit drug or alcohol use problem (9.3
label: BODY

text: percent of persons in that age group).  Of these, 7.1 million persons needed treatment for illicit drug problems,
label: BODY

text: with or without alcohol.13
label: BODY

text: Of the 23.5 million persons needing substance use treatment, 2.6 million received treatment at a specialty facility
label: BODY

text: in the past year, and of the 7.1 million needing drug treatment, 1.5 million received specialty treatment.14
label: BODY

text: Acute Health Effects
label: BODY

text: In 2008, an estimated 2 million visits to emergency departments in US hospitals were associated with drug misuse
label: BODY

text: or abuse, including close to one million (993,379) visits involving an illicit drug.  Nonmedical use of
label: BODY

text: pharmaceuticals was involved in 971,914 visits.15 Cocaine was involved in 482,188 visits, marijuana was
label: BODY

text: involved in 374,435 visits, heroin was involved in 200,666 visits, and stimulants (including amphetamines and
label: BODY

text: methamphetamine) were involved in 91,939 visits.
label: BODY

text: Criminal Justice Involvement
label: BODY

text: According to a 2009 study of arrestees in 10 major metropolitan areas across the country, drug use among the
label: BODY

text: arrestee population is much higher than in the general U.S. population.  The percentage of booked arrestees
label: BODY

text: testing positive for at least one illicit drug ranged from 56 percent to 82 percent.  The most common substances
label: BODY

text: present during tests, in descending order, are marijuana, cocaine, opiates (primarily metabolites of heroin or
label: BODY

text: morphine), and methamphetamine.  Many arrestees tested positive for more than one illegal drug at the time of
label: BODY

text: arrest.16
label: BODY

text: According to a 2004 survey of inmates in correctional facilities, 32 percent of state inmates and 26 percent of
label: BODY

text: federal prisoners reported that they used drugs at the time of the offense.17
label: BODY

text: Environmental Impact and Dangers
label: BODY

text: There are significant environmental impacts from clandestine methamphetamine drug labs, including chemical
label: BODY

text: toxicity, risk of fire and explosion, lingering effects of toxic waste, and potential injuries. The number of domestic
label: BODY

text: meth lab incidents, which includes dumpsites, active labs, and chemical/glassware set-ups, dropped dramatically
label: BODY

text: in response to the Combat Meth Epidemic Act, (CMEA) of 2005, from nearly 13,000 in 2005 to just over 6,000 in
label: BODY

text: 2007. However, traffickers are devising methods to avoid the CMEA restrictions and domestic meth lab incidents
label: BODY

text: are rising again, reaching 9,800 in 2009.18
label: BODY

text: Coca and poppy cultivation in the Andean jungle is significantly damaging the environment in the region.  The
label: BODY

text: primary threats to the environment are deforestation caused by clearing the fields for cultivation, soil erosion, and
label: BODY

text: chemical pollution from insecticides and fertilizers.  Additionally, the lab process of converting coca and poppy
label: BODY

text: into cocaine and heroin has adverse effects on the environment.19
label: BODY

text: Mexican drug trafficking organizations have been operating on public lands in the U.S.  to cultivate marijuana,
label: BODY

text: with serious consequences for the environment and public safety. Propane tanks and other trash from illicit
label: BODY

text: marijuana growers litter the remote areas of park lands from California to Tennessee. Growers often use a cocktail
label: BODY

text: of pesticides and fertilizers many times stronger than what is used on residential lawns to cultivate their crop.
label: BODY

text: These chemicals leach out quickly, killing native insects and other organisms directly.  Fertilizer runoff
label: BODY

text: contaminates local waterways and aids in the growth of algae and weeds. The aquatic vegetation in turn impedes
label: BODY

text: water flows that are critical to maintaining biodiversity in wetlands and other sensitive environments.20
label: BODY
